Award.AwardTitle: Bright and responsive fluorescent nucleosides from structure-photophysics relationships
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Byron Purse of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at San Diego State University is developing next-generation fluorescent nucleosides as tools for studying nucleic acids. In addition to storing the genetic code, nucleic acids have many important regulatory roles in gene expression and metabolism. Fluorescent nucleosides are chemically modified building blocks of nucleic acids that are widely used in biophysical studies aimed at understanding the regulation of gene expression. This project aims to enhance the understanding of the relationship between structure and fluorescence properties of these nucleoside probes, and to use this knowledge to add new capabilities to the toolkit of fluorescent nucleoside analogues. Integral to the research plan is the studying of the fluorescence properties of these new nucleoside analogues in the Physical Chemistry teaching laboratory of San Diego State University and an outreach program targeting high school and community college students in the computational work.

The rational design of fluorescent nucleoside analogues with specifically targeted properties is a great challenge because predicting photo-physical properties based on structure, especially in a complex environment like a nucleic acid duplex, is difficult to achieve. In this project, photophysical studies coupled with density functional theory methods are being used to establish structure-photophysics relationships, in order to develop next-generation fluorescent nucleosides with desired fluorescence properties. The desired fluorescence properties include: (a) large fluorescence turn-on responses to base stacking (i.e. > 100-fold), (b) brightness matching conventional fluorophores, sufficient to enable single-molecule biophysics and tracking of labeled nucleic acids by fluorescence microscopy, and (c) analogues that absorb and emit at the red end of the visible spectrum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research was an enhanced understanding of the relationship between structure and fluorescent properties of nucleoside analogues, and to use this knowledge to create analogues with new capabilities for studying the replication, maintenance, and expression of the genetic code.

Under the category of intellectual merit, the following outcomes were attained. (1) We completed a detailed study on a series of structurally related fluorescent nucleotides placed in double-stranded DNA oligonucleotides of variable sequence. Analysis of the results showed that there are significant relationships between the electronic nature of the fluorescent nucleoside (electron rich or deficient), the electron richness of neighboring nucleobases, and fluorescent responses to base pairing and stacking. We identified nucleoside analogues that turn on their fluorescence in response to incorporation into double-stranded DNA, and we identified useful fluorescent responses to matched or mismatched base pairing. The results of this published work inform other researchers on the selection of fluorescent nucleotides for applications in biophysics and are enabling to the future design of new nucleoside analogue fluorophores with further enhanced properties. (2) We improved synthetic methods for a fluorescent nucleoside analogue DEAtC, which has the most powerful known fluorescence turn-on response to base pairing and stacking. The improved synthetic methods were published to aid in making this compound more readily available to other researchers. (3) Substantial progress was made on next-generation nucleoside analogues with greatly enhanced brightness, which our lab intends to complete and publish in the future.

Under the category of broader impacts, the following outcomes were attained. (1) New fluorescent probes are available to other researchers interested in collaborating with the PI, for many applications in biophysical studies involving nucleic acids. (2) Four graduate students and 14 undergraduates participated directly in this research in the lab of the PI and/or his collaborators. These students are co-authors of the publications resulting from this project. The graduate students are working towards degree completion, and many of the participating undergraduates are now in Ph.D. programs or at medical schools. Two of the graduate students have won merit-based University Graduate Fellowships. Three of the undergraduates were selected for NIH IMSD (Initiative for Maximizing Student Development) awards in support of diversity in STEM. (3) Approximately 30 students participated in fluorescent measurements of nucleoside analogues from this study, focusing on solvent isotope effects to measure quenching by excited-state proton transfer. This experience resulted in an increased interest in STEM careers and several students applying to attend graduate school in chemistry.
